prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. A math textbook with a double-digit number of pages is split into sections. Each section is exactly $12$ pages long, with the exception of the epilogue, which is $11$ pages long. Every page belongs to a section. Furthermore, on the bottom of each $5$th page, a trivia fact is presented on the bottom of the page, starting from the fifth page. If a trivia fact appears on the bottom of the second-to-last page, then how many pages does the textbook have?
gpt_response:
Let $n$ be the total number of pages in the textbook. We know that the epilogue is $11$ pages long, leaving $n-11$ pages for the main sections of the book.

Since each section is $12$ pages long, there are $\frac{n-11}{12}$ sections in the main part of the book. Each section has $12$ pages, so the total number of pages in the main part of the book is $\frac{n-11}{12} \times 12 = n-11$.

If a trivia fact appears on the bottom of the second-to-last page, then it must be on the bottom of the last page of one of the sections in the main part of the book. Since a trivia fact appears on every 5th page starting from the 5th page, the second-to-last page must be a multiple of 5. However, since there is an epilogue of 11 pages, the second-to-last page cannot be the 5th page of any section, so it must be the 10th page of a section.

This means that the total number of pages in the main part of the book is $10$ pages more than a multiple of $12$. This implies that $n-11 \equiv 10 \pmod{12}$. Hence, $n \equiv 9 \pmod{12}$.

Furthermore, since the book has a double-digit number of pages, we know that $n \geq 10$. Combining this with $n \equiv 9 \pmod{12}$, we find that the possible solutions are $n = 9, 21, 33, 45, ...$.

However, the book must have more than $11$ pages in total since the epilogue is $11$ pages long. Therefore, the only possible solution is $n=21$.

Thus, the textbook has $21$ pages.
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response 71?: Let $n$ be the total number of pages in the textbook. We know that the epilogue is $11$ pages long, leaving $n-11$ pages for the main sections of the book.

This means that the total number of pages in the main part of the book is $10$ pages more than a multiple of $12$. This implies that $n-11 \equiv 10 \pmod{12}$. Hence, $n \equiv 9 \pmod{12}$.

However, the book must have more than $11$ pages in total since the epilogue is $11$ pages long. Therefore, the only possible solution is $n=21$.
